vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/fd5cb368-4b51-44f6-970c-908acad4bf55">WAGES</keyword>         <topcClas>Income, property and investment - Economics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Management and organisation - Industry and management</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Business Expenditure on Research and Development</i> is an annual survey whose main purpose is to supply data for policy purposes on Science and Technology, of which Research and Development is an important part. It uniquely provides information on total Research and Development expenditure in the UK by business enterprises, total Research and Development employment and sources of funds. Data are used on a regular basis by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the Statistical Office of the European Communities (EUROSTAT) for international comparisons in their publications.<br> <br> <i>Geographical references: postcodes</i><br> The postcodes available in these data prior to 2009 are pseudo-anonymised postcodes.  The real postcodes were not available due to the potential risk of identification of the observations.  However, these replacement postcodes retain the inherent nested characteristics of real postcodes, and will allow researchers to aggregate observations to other geographic units, e.g. wards, super output areas, etc.<br> <br> <i>Linking to other business studies</i><br> These data contain Inter-Departmental Business Register reference numbers.  These are anonymous but unique reference numbers assigned to business organisations.  Their inclusion allows researchers to combine different business survey sources together.  Researchers may consider applying for other business data to assist their research.<br> <br> The fourth edition (February 2015) includes provisional data for 2013, as well as revised data for 2011 and 2012.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The Reporting Units surveyed receive either a 'long form' or 'short form'. The long form asks for information on:<ul><li>in-house expenditure on Research and Development:<ul><li>broken down by product group and purpose (civil or defence)</li><li>broken down by funding sources: central government; private industry and public corporations; overseas EC programmes; overseas; own funds; other</li><li>current expenditure broken down by  basic research; applied research; and experimental research</li><li>capital expenditure  broken down by land and buildings; and plant and machinery</li></ul><li>Research and Development commissioned outside the company</li><li>number of employees working on Research and Development broken down by scientists and engineers; technicians; others</li></ul>Smaller firms receive a short form. This only asks for a breakdown of Research and Development by civil and defence for three questions. It requests aggregate figures for Intramural Research and Development (including both current and capital expenditure), purchasing of Research and Development (work conducted outside the company, funded by the business) and average employment on Research and Development (number of full time equivalents). Figures are constructed for those that filled in the short form to cover all the variables covered by the long form. For certain variables, values are imputed from third party sources or estimated rather than returned by respondents. All the un-sampled firms have figures imputed for the entire variable list.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1994-01-01T00:00:00Z">01 January 1994</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2013-12-31T00:00:00Z">31 December 2013</timePrd>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Postcode (Unit)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Postcode (Unit) [anonymised]</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Institutions/organisations</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>UK organisations that contributed to overall Research and Development activity and that were registered for VAT and/or PAYE in 1994 - 2013.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Office for National Statistics</dataCollector>         <sampProc>One-stage stratified or systematic random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>Approximately 3,500 - 26,000 organisations</deviat>         <collMode>Postal survey</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>No weighting used.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Secure data</specPerm>         <restrctn>Registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. Controlled data requirements and conditions also apply. Further information is available from <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/accesssecurelab.aspx'>Access to the Secure Lab</a>. In addition, the Service is required to request explicit permission from the data owner prior to providing the researcher with access to the data.<br> Available to UK HE/FE applicants only. <p>Please note:<br>Since these data are more sensitive and/or pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence or under a Special Licence, they are not available for download but may be accessed through Secure Access. Access requires accreditation by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher, completion of face-to-face training, and agreement to the Secure Access's <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176858/ukda140_sds_sdsagreement_public.pdf'>User Agreement</a> and <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176861/UKDA142_SDS_SecurityBreaches_public.pdf'>Breaches Penalties Policy</a>. This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. Applications are screened by the UK Data Archive and the Office for National Statistics, and access is only granted to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the data. Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'> Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>6699 UK Innovation Survey, 1994-2012: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>Clayton, T. et al. (2014) <I>Private and external benefits from investment in intangible assets</I>, BIS Research Paper 203, London: Department for Business, Innovation and Skills.<br></relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
